thread.title: Golf: Great season for North Jersey players - Golf
thread.title_full: Golf: Great season for North Jersey players - Golf - NorthJersey.com

author: GREG MATTURA
title: Golf: Great season for North Jersey players - Golf
text:
As New Jersey’s golf season draws to a close, two former North Jersey high school stars will settle one final score.
Tyler Hall and Brian Mackey are neck and neck for the New Jersey PGA Section Assistant Player of the Year honors, and it will be decided at Monday’s Assistant Players Championship at Crestmont Country Club in West Orange.
"To win the Assistant Player of the Year, that would be huge," said Hall, 34, a 1999 Wayne Valley graduate and director of instruction at Upper Montclair in Clifton.
"To have the opportunity to win Player of the Year is surreal," said Mackey, 30, a 2004 graduate of St. Joseph in Montvale and an assistant at White Beeches in Haworth.
North Jersey golfers, pro and amateur, produced arguably their finest season in the 21st century.
Homegrown stars excelled on the PGA and LPGA tours. Wyckoff native Morgan Hoffmann, 26, made his debut at The Masters en route to retaining his PGA Tour card. Wayne’s Marina Alex, 25, secured her LPGA card by making the cut at all five majors.
Oradell’s Jim McGovern, head pro at White Beeches, excelled during his freshman season on the senior circuit. McGovern, 50, won the New Jersey Senior Open in May and qualified for the U.S. Senior Open and British Senior Open.
Franklin Lakes’ Trevor Randolph became the first Bergen County resident to win the Bergen County Amateur since 2000. Randolph, 42, followed that September victory later in the month by winning the Metropolitan Golf Association’s Mid-Amateur.
Hall, in his first full season back in Wayne after a decade playing mini-tours, won the New Jersey Open in July in a seven-stroke runaway. He was runner-up at the Met Open in August.
"It’s been a great year," said Hall, who leads Mackey by four points in the Assistant standings, 533-529. "I’ve been very fortunate to have played well."
Mackey has joined the Garden State’s top tier. He tied for 12th at the New Jersey Open. He won the NJPGA Assistant Championship in August. At last month’s final of the Assistant Season Long Match Play, he topped Hall on the first playoff hole.
"It’s all very exciting, and it’s nice to have been pretty consistent this season," said Mackey. "It’s probably the best I’ve played in quite some time."
